reviewText:
READ THIS REVIEW BEFORE PURCHASING, PLEASE

I have purchased this game for the Nintendo Wii, the Xbox 360, and now the PC via Steam, and I feel confident in saying that the Xbox 360 version is hands-down the best version of the game, and that the version sold on Steam is hands-down the worst version for a number of reasons, which I will now give to you:

First of all, right after download, the game WON'T WORK FOR YOU. I cannot stress this emphatically enough: IT WILL NOT WORK. The game requires Games For Windows Marketplace
date: a completely unrelated and obscure Microsoft download (not normally included in Windows) to be running, and then if the stars align the file MIGHT start up (after starting three times in a row for me, the fourth time  it decided that it was done). This is pretty frustrating for what is essentially a kids' game.\n\nIF (and that's a pretty big if") you get the game running
recommended: the second major issue is controller support. The Steam description touts "Full controller support
hoursPlayed: but this is not entirely accurate or true. I am using a wireless Xbox 360 controller with a USB dongle, which works flawlessly on all of the dozens of games in my library which were released after 2008 -- but not this one. The game has trouble recognizing that a controller is present, and seems to forget that one is connected quite frequently. Again, when the stars align and you do have the game running and the controller working, it does finally begin to resemble the Xbox 360 game in terms of playability, even if the game is not coded to display the Xbox 360 buttons, instead opting to show generic controller buttons (for example, the yellow Y" 360 button is mapped to a gray "1"). This in itself is not that big of a deal
voteText: but it isn't good for young children using the Microsoft product.\n\nI honestly wish I could tell you more about the gameplay
helpfulPercent: but the chances are that you'll never see it which is a shame (although a little "floaty
votesHelpful: the game is worth it for the Woody's Round-up" segment alone
votesTotal: which rewards exploration and quests with a lot of genuinely fun unlockable content). This version is a complete waste of money and time. If you already own an Xbox 360 and are looking for something to play with a child
column17: which has great visuals and two-player splitscreen co-op in a world filled with quests
column18: upgrades and exploration. If you have no friends and hate yourself
column20: which omits 2-player and replaces good old-fashioned button presses with wildly unpredictable waggling motion controls. As for the Steam version...\n\nThis Steam version is only for three types of people: 1.) Software developers who enjoy figuring out why a program doesn't work and Rube-Goldberging a solution 2.) Conscientious software pirates who want to own a legitimate copy of the game they torrented before the government finds them 3.) Richard Pryor in the movie "Brewster's Millions" (I feel this last one is self-explanatory
column21: but in case you haven't seen it
column22: he has to spend one million dollars in a very limited time on in order to win a larger inheritance
column23: the rub being at the ethat nd of the time alotted he has to have nothing to show for it
column24: which descrbes this game perfectly).\n\nEveryone else should just avoid it at all costs."

reviewText:
This game should NOT be available on Steam. I first installed it on my son's computer (set up as a Steam game console). First it constantly crashed on boot. Once I fixed that (requiring the installation of a no CD hack... seriously) it was supposed to be controller compatible. It is, but not until after you use the mouse to click on Start. Since I have his computer set up as a came console there is no keyboard or mouse connected. Then once you actually start the game it's choppy as hell and unplayable.

I tried running it in compatibility mode and that didn't fix any of the problems. His system runs Windows 7, so on a whim I tried on my Windows 10 PC. Exact same issues.

Do not buy this game on Steam. The PC version, or at the very least the digital version, is broken and unplayable. It's also falsely advertised as being fully controller compatible which is not true.

reviewText:
Toy Story 3: The Video Game is a platform game loosely based on the film Toy Story 3. Almost the entire Toy Story case from the films return in voice acting, apart from the two key characters, Buzz and Woody, for me, it is an absolute shame that they didn't get Tom Hanks and Tim Allen in...

Game play wise, Toy Story 3 is a platformer, where players control either Woody, Buzz or Jessie. Each of the characters have their own special move. There are two main modes in the game, Story and Toybox. The story mode has nine levels, this follows the events in the movie, as well as the opening sequence from Toy Story 2. Toybox mode, you can create and customize levels, fill it with inhabitants and missions. Completing various objectives and missions in this mode, you will earn money, which in turn can be used to purchase new objects, toys and to expand your city. Some of the characters are also from other Disney and Pixar franchises!

It almost looks as if you are watching the movie with the graphics on show here; it's a shame I couldn't play it in full 1080p, the resolution option just wasn't available. Also I was disappointed to see that it is capped at 30 FPS,  so it would look even better if you could play it on a proper resolution/frame rate...

All of the levels are well presented, there are a copious amount of jumping puzzles, and BOOOOOOOOOOOY do I love jumping puzzles.....You will be playing in well known locations such as Andy's bedroom, Sunnyside Daycare and Junkyards. All of these look amazing and filled with lots of little nuts and crannies to explorer. My favorite level is the one based on the Buzz Lightyear Video game (the one Rex plays), it just resonates nostalgia. Everything is there from the laser eye, to the wall of spikes, to the secret passage on the left.

I have to admit, I did struggle at times with a number of the jumping puzzles, but then again, I struggle with them on any game,  other than that, there aren't any real hard points,  that should be expected from a game mainly based at the younger audience though.

Sadly the main issue I have with Toy Story 3 The Video game, is the length. I finished the story, all of the side missions and most of the collectibles in just under two hours. To me that is unacceptable for a game of this stature, I would of been satisfied if it was maybe five hours, but two hours is just not on. There is so much more which could of been included into the story mode to flesh it out.

With that being said, if you grew up with Toy Story, you will have so many memories and nostalgia towards the whole gang, and you will more than likely get a lot of enjoyment with this game if only for those reasons only. I would certainly not recommend anyone pick this up at full price. Sadly since it is a Disney title, it probably won't go on sale very often, so keep your eyes out.

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

http://store.steampowered.com/app/300820

reviewText:
AVOID THE STEAM VERSION!!!!
Before I bought it, I knew it was a Wii port and I knew what to expect. And i was fine with it. But when I isntalled it, the game wouldn't even run. It needed a no-cd patch to run it, which is not what I expected when buying the game.
I ran it and it was quite well, but the only problem is, that all in-game voices in POLISH version are in CZECH. the only way (I think) to play it is replacing Czech voice files with those from English version.
I would recommend the game, because I like it, but if you can buy it in DRM-free/Retail version, just do it.
AVOID THE STEAM VERSION!!!!

reviewText:
I didn't want it to be true but it is.. and I'm saying this as a BIG Toy Story fan (also a lot of childhood memories). =(
This is a very disappointing port of a console to computer" game!
IF the game should work (which it only did once at the first time I started) you'll see that the graphic quality from the console-version is not being carried over into the PC-version (bad to no shading and missing face animations) and I'm not sure if it's the port/pc-version or the fact that I have the german language setting but none of the charakters make the slightest noise or say a sentence during the levels/gameplay.
You'll end up with silent and creepily staring charakters and missing conversations which are supposed to explain you your mission.

The biggest problem like fellow Steam-Users "haha:)" and "Solo|cF" already pointed out
date: THE GAME DOES NOT WORK!!\nIn my case I was lucky to play it once
recommended: but starting it again caused the error "Game Application has stopped working" and there seems to be no easy or difficult way to solve this problem. (And yes my computer DOES fulfill the system requirements by far.)\n\nBeing disappointed about a game because it's bad or not entertaining is one thing
hoursPlayed: but not working is a complete outrage! Especially for a game you payed!!\n\nSo the only reasonable solution is to take down the game of steam because IT IS NOT WORKING + a refund for the people that bought the game or at least to get an update for Toy Story 3 which'll fix the main problem
voteText: the fact that it causes the error "Game Application has stopped working" making it unplayable.\n\nP.S. everyone who reads this
helpfulPercent: please flag the game to get steams attention! :)"
